metadata.title: Data Who?. Data Profession Key Positions —… | by Inbal Gilead | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: An oldie but goodie.. What’s the difference between a Data Analyst and a Data Scientist? a BI Analyst and a Business Analyst? a Data Architect and a Data Engineer? Data profession and positions have…

all_paragraphs: An oldie but goodie.. What’s the difference between a Data Analyst and a Data Scientist? a BI Analyst and a Business Analyst? a Data Architect and a Data Engineer?

Data profession and positions have drastically changed over the past few years, new positions emerged, old definitions no longer apply and it can be very hard to define your adequate title, even harder to find the persona to fill your need when recruiting.

A few years ago while I was trying to recruit a Junior Data Analyst for my team, I created the following Dictionary of Data Positions. Although not full, as new positions are constantly being formed, it can hopefully help some of you arrange your thoughts when structuring your teams or measuring yourselves against the market and mapping your skills.

Uses a wide range of tools such as predictive models, statistical algorithms and data mining to tackle data related issues.Often works in a per case tailored approach, steering wide operations with analysis results. Loves raw data, knows when to deep dive and when to model, has (or will produce for you) — ALL the answers.Technically minded persona with a proactive practical approach.
Favorite task: Applying data models to derive insights

Problem solver. Researches potential solutions, both known and unknown for the issues in question, weigh them considering the ecosystem from which the business requirements came from and available data at hand to the point of choosing the preferred solution and transforming it from research to product.
Favorite task: Experiment with applying new research as a solution for a business problem

Paves the path, constructs scalable, maintainable and stable pipelines through which the entire organizational data flows to be analyzed. Balances professional engineering with experimental data application requirements.
Favorite task: Integrate a new data stream into the organizational data pipeline

Creates and maintains a cross organizational standard for data storage and consumption. Aligns data initiatives with the technical framework and business goals, identifies strategic moves and optimization opportunities. Designer of the organizational data jungle gym.
Favorite task: Design the consumption of a new data stream
BI AnalystCryptologist, translates data into insights

Produces actionable insights based on existing data to induce and support decision making in the organization. Both maintain and change the business by analyzing data into understanding the past and evaluating the present. Reporting professional with a strong business perspective.
Favorite task: Provide actionable insights for business stakeholders
Business Analyst (Marketing, Product, System, Financial..)Data author and storyteller

A data-savvy business expert. Less worried about collecting the data and more focused on the business angle comparing to the BI analyst. This analyst is an expert in her field, fully committed to supporting defined business goals with data (though the analysis wont necessarily be quantitative), while always keeping in mind the organization's efficiency and profitability.
Favorite task: Research a business issue by collecting relevant data making decisions clear and simple
Data Governance AnalystGatekeeper of organizational data

Monitors Organizational data cross system and sources. Analyses issues such as data discrepancies, availability and consistency to improve confidence in data. Quality oriented, controller of data flows.
Favorite task: Analyze irregular production measurements to discover a root cause

Identifies needs and potential wins of data usage in and around company products. Defines data deliverables that can either be a part of an existing product or standalone as a data product to be used by consumers (internal or external). Strategist and visionary of data-driven products, shapes the frame in which data professionals operate.
Favorite task: Define a data solution for a business problem
Generally speaking, all data professionals' skills can be mapped into 3 main areas with different levels of proficiency in each;
Mapping the different positions as described above to those areas of skills, looks something like this:

Not all data groups in all companies will include all the above positions, and certainly not as individual team members. In small companies, it’s very common to have a few stakeholders responsible for the entire spectrum end to end. However, it’s my tip to you — the way you choose the persona for this position will highly affect your expected output, so choose wisely.

For example, a Data Scientist and Data Engineer responsibilities can sometimes be unified under the same person. However, you’ll be wise to consider what you really need; a Data Scientist with engineering capabilities or an Engineer with data science orientation?
Similarly, when defining what type of analyst you are, consider these: are you more about the data or the business use case? are you a field expert or a proficient reporter of facts?
I’m sure my definitions are not fully aligned with every professional you know, maybe not even with how you define yourself.

However, I hope it still helps you understand the data profession ecosystem we work in and raises some points for you to consider next time you turn to recruit/ learn a new skill/ reposition your career and alike.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Expert in data-driven decision making, data analytics, and product development.
